thread.title: Roosters flatten Wests Tigers to prove their NRL premiership credentials
thread.title_full: Roosters flatten Wests Tigers to prove their NRL premiership credentials | The Courier-Mail

author: couriermail.com.au
title: Roosters flatten Wests Tigers to prove their NRL premiership credentials
text:
This could be the first and last time the Sydney Roosters lose a game the rest of this season.
That’s when competition leaders Brisbane travel down to meet the Chooks.
It will be a belter. Unlike Friday night.
Other than Wayne Bennett’s men, who stands a chance of beating the Roosters?
Canterbury await them next Friday. They’ll have a dig, but the Roosters will be ready.
Even when they play bad, the Tricolours have a knack of putting sides away by a big score.
They did it against the Wests Tigers.
Their first half was ordinary. They missed 10 tackles, and completed just 13 of 19 sets, which is normally unheard of from the Bondi boys.
Something seemed a little off about their opening 40 minutes.
CRUISING: Late controversy as Roosters rout Tigers
LISTEN TO OUR ROUND 20 SUPERCOACH PODCAST
But then they put the foot down.
“We moved the ball around without too much rhythm at the start. The second half I thought our bench forward paved the way ... and with a bit more patience, we ended up getting tries,’’ coach Trent Robinson said.
The Roosters are deserved title favourites. If you’ve got a spare $20 in your wallet this morning, hold off on the brunch and plonk it on the Cowboys-Roosters grand final.
Broncos fans pumped about their own side’s big win on Friday night wouldn’t have felt as great if they tuned into Channel 9 to see the Roosters on the delayed game.
That’s now six wins on the trot. They’ve won eight of their past nine.
The only thing that could bring the Roosters undone is their mindset.
Roger Tuivasa-Sheck was in sensational form for the Roosters. Source: AAP
So far the Shaun Kenny-Dowall situation hasn’t proven a distraction for the players on the field. Robinson will make sure it stays that way.
Wests Tigers fullback James Tedesco, who was again a star in a beaten side, was well placed to give his opinion on the premiership merits of the Broncos and Roosters, two teams he’s played in the last five days.
“Personally I thought the Broncos were strong all over the park, and their defence was quite hard to crack. The Roosters have the team to go all the way, it’s just if they can play consistently for the whole 80 minutes, and if they do they’ll be hard to stop,’’ Tedesco said.
Tigers coach Jason Taylor actually believed his side ‘’were good enough to win the game, and I think we should have won it’’.
“We beat ourselves, I don’t feel the Roosters beat us,’’ Taylor said.
 Classy Roosters prove their credentials
